G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u202f28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court “may make a judgment modifying any earlier judgment as to custody or visitation if the Court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The law of the Commonwealth is well-settled that a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focused on the ‘cause shown’/best interests standard when parents share joint physical and legal custody. It does not state or apply the general rule for modification of custody or parenting-time orders upon a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances.’ The only reference to “substantial change in circumstances” appears in a quoted ALI Principles provision about relocation, not as a statement of Massachusetts’ settled law governing modification of custody or parenting-time orders generally.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] ...”
...
“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ...”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The law of the Commonwealth is well-settled that a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Vaughn is focused on the need for explicit findings regarding the impact of domestic violence on a child in custody determinations. It does not discuss the standards or legal test for modifying an existing custody or parenting-time order, nor does it reference the “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition about modification of custody orders.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The best interests of the child govern all custody determinations in Massachusetts.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets the governing statute (G.L. c. 208, § 30) to mean that removal decisions must be based on the best interests of the child and repeatedly states that the children’s best interests are the paramount concern. Although the case focuses on removal and physical custody rather than all possible custody disputes, its reasoning treats best interests as the controlling standard in custody-related determinations in Massachusetts.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The best interests of the child govern all custody determinations in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the governing standard for custody determinations and reiterates that the ‘best interests of the child’ is the controlling principle in Massachusetts custody law. It traces the historical use of the best-interests standard in Massachusetts cases and applies that standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) to resolve the custody dispute, making clear that custody is to be awarded as appropriate in the child’s best interests. Thus, it supports the proposition that the best interests of the child govern all custody determinations in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly … as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”}

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u202f20.proposition: G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (applicable to parenting orders for unmarried parents);

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u202f6.proposition: G.L. c. 215, § 6 (granting Probate Court equitable jurisdiction);

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that as a child grows older, the parenting plan should evolve accordingly to suit changing developmental and practical needs.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion is about modification of custody and removal from the Commonwealth; it applies the ‘material and substantial change’ and Yannas ‘real advantage’ standards. It does not discuss or endorse any general principle that parenting plans should evolve as a child ages or that Massachusetts law recognizes age‑based developmental changes as a reason to adjust parenting plans over time. Any references to the child’s development are case‑specific and not framed as a broader doctrinal rule about evolving parenting plans with age.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… ‘The uprooting of a child… should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that as a child grows older, the parenting plan should evolve accordingly to suit changing developmental and practical needs.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The opinion is about the constitutionality and construction of the Massachusetts grandparent visitation statute and associated due process and equal protection concerns. It does not discuss parenting plans, custodial schedules, or any principle that a parenting plan should evolve as a child grows older. Nothing in the reasoning addresses age-related modification of parenting arrangements, so this case does not support the claimed proposition.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: The statute adopts the “best interests of the child” standard as the test for determining visitation. This standard has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation and other issues relating to child welfare. The statute, however, uses the standard in a new context, and, based on the reasoning in the Troxel case, the standard, left unspecified, cannot survive a due process challenge.

Miller v. Todd, 952 N.E.2d 1005 (Mass. A.raw_text: Miller v. Todd, 952 N.E.2d 1005 (Mass. App. Ct. 2011)
Miller v. Todd, 952 N.E.2d 1005 (Mass. A.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that as a child grows older, the parenting plan should evolve accordingly to suit changing developmental and practical needs.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Additional authority supporting this Court’s power and obligations in determining the best interests of the child includes:
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition is that Rolde is additional authority on the court’s power and obligations to determine the child’s best interests. The opinion expressly states that in custody matters the court’s overriding concern must be the best interests and welfare of the children, describes that as the judge’s duty, and applies that standard to affirm the custody and visitation orders. Thus it directly supports citing the case for the court’s authority and obligation to determine and protect the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the children] should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future….’”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Additional authority supporting this Court’s power and obligations in determining the best interests of the child includes:
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the removal question as one requiring a best-interests-of-the-child analysis and emphasizes the court’s responsibility to consider all relevant factors, including the welfare of the custodial parent and alternative visitation arrangements. The Appeals Court reverses and remands because the probate judge’s best-interests determination was too narrow, thereby affirming both the court’s power and its obligation to conduct a comprehensive best-interests inquiry when making decisions critically affecting children. This aligns with citing the case as additional authority on the court’s power and obligations in determining the child’s best interests.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We are concerned that the judge may have had too narrow a focus in making this decision of critical significance to the lives of both of these parents and their children, we reverse and remand for further proceedings.… Because sensitive and significant child-parent relationships are affected by decisions concerning removal, we think that there is here also the need for comprehensive findings and that the interests of the child may be best served by an accommodation ‘which intrudes least on the [liberties] of either parent and is yet compatible with the health of the child.’”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Additional authority supporting this Court’s power and obligations in determining the best interests of the child includes:
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody determinations the governing principle is the welfare of the child, and characterizes this as a matter of law and humanity, thereby affirming the court’s power and obligation to determine custody based on the child’s best interests. The court applies that standard to uphold a custody award with no visitation, reinforcing its authority and duty to make such best‑interests determinations.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … ‘[T]he happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child….’”
